Sentencas: Nitrogen is often used as an inert background atmosphere in solid state studies of electrode and reaction kinetics, of solid state studies of transport phenomena, and in applications e.g. solid oxide fuel cells (SOFC), sensors and membranes.
Titulo: Electrochemical activation of molecular nitrogen at the Ir/YSZ interface

Sentencas: Thus, chemical and electrochemical reactions of oxides related to or with dinitrogen are not supposed and in general not considered.
Titulo: Electrochemical activation of molecular nitrogen at the Ir/YSZ interface

Sentencas: We demonstrate by a steady state electrochemical polarisation experiments complemented with in situ photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) that at a temperature of 450 degrees C dinitrogen can be electrochemically activated at the three phase boundary between N-2, a metal microelectrode and one of the most widely used solid oxide electrolytes-yttria stabilized zirconia (YSZ)-at potentials more negative than E = -1.25
Titulo: Electrochemical activation of molecular nitrogen at the Ir/YSZ interface

Sentencas: V. The process is neither related to a reduction of the electrolyte nor to an adsorption process or a purely chemical reaction but is electrochemical in nature.
Titulo: Electrochemical activation of molecular nitrogen at the Ir/YSZ interface

Sentencas: Only at potentials more negative than E = -2 V did new components of Zr 3d and Y 3d signals with a lower formal charge appear, thus indicating electrochemical reduction of the electrolyte matrix.
Titulo: Electrochemical activation of molecular nitrogen at the Ir/YSZ interface

Sentencas: Theoretical model calculations suggest the presence of anionic intermediates with delocalized electrons at the electrode/electrolyte reaction interface.
Titulo: Electrochemical activation of molecular nitrogen at the Ir/YSZ interface

Sentencas: The ex situ SIMS analysis confirmed that nitrogen is incorporated and migrates into the electrolyte beneath the electrode.
Titulo: Electrochemical activation of molecular nitrogen at the Ir/YSZ interface
